speaker: Doctor
text: So you're experiencing behavior issues at school and at home. Can you tell me more about what's been going on and how you've been feeling lately?

speaker: Patient
text: "I don't know, doc. I just feel like I don't have to listen to anyone sometimes. My teacher is always telling me what to do, and it gets really annoying. I just want to do my own thing."

speaker: Doctor
text: "Okay, it sounds like you're feeling a bit frustrated with the rules and expectations at school. Can you tell me more about what happens when you feel like you don't have to listen to anyone? Do you ever feel like you're getting into trouble or getting in trouble with your parents?"

speaker: Patient
text: "Honestly, doc, I don't really think about it too much. I just do what I want, and if my parents get mad, that's their problem. I mean, I'm 9 years old, I should be able to make my own decisions, right?"

speaker: Doctor
text: "Making your own decisions can be a big responsibility, but it's also important to consider how your actions affect others. Can you tell me more about what happens when you do decide to do something that might upset your parents or others?"

speaker: Patient
text: "Like, I'll just do what I want, and if they get mad, I'll just tell them I'm sorry. I don't really think about how it's going to affect them, I just do what feels right to me. And it's not always what they want me to do, so that's okay."

speaker: Doctor
text: "Okay, it sounds like you're feeling pretty confident in your own decisions, and you're not too concerned about how others might feel. Can you tell me more about what happens when you're doing something that you know your parents or teacher might not agree with?"

speaker: Patient
text: "Like, I'll just do it anyway, doc. I mean, if my parents or teacher are mad, I'll just tell them I was sorry and that I'll try to do it differently next time. But I don't see why they can't just let me do what I want sometimes. It's not hurting anyone, right?"

speaker: Doctor
text: It sounds like you're feeling pretty confident in your own decisions and you're not too concerned about how others might feel. Can you tell me more about what happens when you're feeling really upset or angry, and how you manage those feelings?

speaker: Patient
text: "Honestly, doc, when I'm feeling really upset or angry, I just try to calm down on my own. I'll take some deep breaths, count to ten, or go outside to play with my sister. She's always good at calming me down, and I like playing with her. It usually helps me feel better, but sometimes I still feel mad and want to do something, like throw a toy or something."

speaker: Doctor
text: So you have a bit of a calming mechanism that helps you when you're feeling upset or angry. Can you tell me more about what happens when you're feeling calm and in control, and how you think about your actions and decisions when you're not feeling upset or angry?

speaker: Patient
text: "I don't know, doc. When I'm feeling calm, I guess I just think about what's fair and what's not. Like, if my teacher is telling me to do something that's not fair, I'll just say no or ask why. speaker: Doctor
text: "Exactly, that's a great summary. Self-compassion is about treating yourself with kindness and understanding, just as you would a close friend. It's not about being perfect, but about acknowledging that you're doing the best you can, and that it's okay to make mistakes. And focusing on the present moment and what you can control is a great way to reduce stress and anxiety. Remember, you can't control everything, but you can control how you respond to situations. By focusing on what you can control, you can feel more calm and in control. Now, I'd like to give you a small homework assignment to continue working on your self-compassion skills. I want you to write down three things you can be kind to yourself about today. It can be something as simple as 'I'm doing a great job of taking care of myself' or 'I'm proud of myself for trying something new.' text: "Okay, I think I understand what you mean by self-compassion. So, it's like being kind to myself and not beating myself up when I make mistakes? And it's also about focusing on the present moment and what I can control, rather than worrying about the past or future?" "Exactly, that's a great summary. Self-compassion is about treating yourself with kindness and understanding, just as you would a close friend. It's not about being perfect, but about acknowledging that you're doing the best you can, and that it's okay to make mistakes. And focusing on the present moment and what you can control is a great way to reduce stress and anxiety. Remember, you can't control everything, but you can control how you respond to situations. By focusing on what you can control, you can feel more calm and in control. Now, I'd like to give you a small homework assignment to continue working on your self-compassion skills.
